text: <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was first described as a T cell product with proinflammatory properties [ 5 , 22 ] .
RA is characterized by hyperplasia of synovial lining cells and an intense infiltration by mononuclear cells [ 23 ] .

Proinflammatory cytokines such as <extra_id_0> IL-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are abundant in rheumatoid synovium , whereas the T cell-derived cytokines , especially <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> interferon-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , have often proved difficult to detect in RA synovium [ 24 ] .
Although T cells may have a role in the augmentation of rheumatoid synovial inflammation , the lack of T cell-derived cytokines has limited its importance .
In this respect , <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is appealing because it has been described as a T cell-derived cytokine with proinflammatory properties .
In our studies , we tried to evaluate how <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production is regulated in RA PBMC , and which signaling pathway it used .
Levels of <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> were found to be higher in RA synovial fluid than in OA synovial fluid [ 15 ] .

However , there are few data available on the agents that stimulate <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production in RA , although the highest level of <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production can be achieved by anti-CD3 / anti - <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> stimulation in healthy individuals [ 25 ] .

In our experiments , <extra_id_0> PHA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as mitogens , as well as anti-CD3 / anti - <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> for signaling through the T cell receptor , increased <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production from RA PBMC in a dose - dependent manner .

We found , by a cell proliferation assay ( data not shown ) , that this upregulation of <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> might be due to increased cellular activity rather than to cellular proliferation .

<extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is produced mainly by activated <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells , especially for Th1 / Th0 cells , not the Th2 phenotype [ 26 ] .

However , it can also be produced by <extra_id_0> CD8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells via an <extra_id_0> IL-23 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> triggering mechanism in Gram - negative pulmonary infection [ 14 ] .
In addition , <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production was significantly augmented by T cells recognizing type II collagen in a collagen - induced arthritis model [ 27 ] .
A complex interaction between cells in inflamed RA joints might produce a variety of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines , which also activate other cells in the joints .

For example , <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> stimulates rheumatoid synoviocytes to secrete several cytokines such as <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor-stimulated gene 6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as well as prostaglandin E2 in vitro [ 12 , 28 , 29 ] .

There are as yet few data available on the agents that stimulate <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production in RA , although some cytokines ( <extra_id_0> IL-15 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-23 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) have been known to regulate <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production [ 13 , 14 ] .

We therefore investigated the in vitro production of <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA PBMC responding to a variety of cytokines / chemokines and mitogens as well as T cell receptor ( TCR ) ligation using anti-CD3 / anti - <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Our studies demonstrated that <extra_id_0> IL-15 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> MCP-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as well as TCR ligation significantly increased the production of <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA PBMC .

Adding <extra_id_0> IL-15 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> MCP-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to TCR ligation augmented <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production more markedly .

In contrast , <extra_id_0> IL-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which are known to have proinflammatory properties and to be increased in RA joints , did not affect <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production .

Our data were consistent with a recent report that <extra_id_0> IL-15 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> triggered in vitro <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production in PBMC , but <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> did not do so [ 13 ] .

Although there were no data that <extra_id_0> MCP-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> directly induces T cell activation , it might exert effects indirectly on T cells through the activation of monocytes / macrophages in PBMC cultures .

As reported for normal individuals [ 25 ] , T cell activation through anti-CD3 / anti - <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> also increases <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction in RA PBMC .

Although the signaling pathway for the induction of cytokines / chemokines by <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has been documented widely [ 8 , 30 , 31 ] , no data have been available on how <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production can be regulated by certain signaling pathways .
By using signal transduction inhibitors , we therefore examined which signaling pathway was mainly involved in the induction of <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA PBMC .

We identified that anti - <extra_id_0> CD3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production in RA PBMC was significantly hampered by the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 and the NF-kappaB inhibitor PDTC to comparable levels of basal production without stimulation .
We also found that anti-CD3 - induced <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production was downregulated by the addition of SB203580 , a p38 MAPK inhibitor .
It is interesting that a series of evidence supports crosstalk between NF-kappaB and p38 .

In myocytes , <extra_id_0> IkappaB kinase-beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is activated by p38 [ 32 ] , and the activated p38 can stimulate NF-kappaB by a mechanism involving histone acetylase <extra_id_0> p300 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> CREB-binding protein <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 33 ] .

Our results revealed that p38 MAPK activation was not affected by LY294002 , whereas NF-kappaB binding activity was decreased by LY294002 , which provided the evidence for a p38 MAPK pathway independent of PI3K activation .
The direct relationship between p38 and NF-kappaB for <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production needs to be studied in future experiments .
The search for a downstream pathway of PI3K seemed to have a maximal response of <extra_id_0> Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation at 1 hour and a gradual loss of activity at 2 hours .

The fact that <extra_id_0> Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is phosphorylated upon anti-CD3 stimulation suggests the possible involvement of PI3K in the induction of <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA .

In view of the fact that NF-kappaB was also activated by anti-CD3 / anti - <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-15 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or mitogens in our experiments , it is most likely that the NF-kappaB pathway is also actively involved in the induction of <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA PBMC .

In contrast , the <extra_id_0> AP-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signal transduction pathway , another important signaling pathway for cytokines / chemokines , was not activated in our experiments ( data not shown ) .

Although PI3K and its downstream kinase <extra_id_0> Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in association with NF-kappaB have been reported to deliver activating signals in many cell types , the data on the signal inducing <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are lacking .

Our data clearly demonstrated that PI3K / <extra_id_0> Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and resultant NF-kappaB activation could be an important arbitrator of the upregulation of <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA , on the basis of our experiments showing simultaneous blocking of NF-kappaB binding activity in the <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter by PDTC and LY294002 .

Considering its proinflammatory activities and successful induction of anti - <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> for ameliorating arthritis in animal models [ 2 , 6 , 34 - 36 ] , understanding the <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling pathway is an important element of developing new targeted therapies in RA .
